div.div: πρί̄ν (πρό): (1) adv., before, formerly, first; πρίν μιν καὶ γῆρας ἔπεισιν, ‘sooner’ shall old age come upon her, Il. 1.29, Il. 24.551, Od. 3.117; freq. τὸ πρίν, πολὺ πρίν, Od. 2.167.—(2) conj., before, with some peculiarities of construction which may be learned from the grammars; the inf. is used more freely with πρίν in Homer than in other authors. Freq. doubled in correlation, πρὶν.. πρίν, Θ 452, Il. 1.97; so πάρος.. πρίν, πρόσθεν.. πρίν, πρίν γ᾽ ὅτε, πρίν γ̓ ἤ (priusquam), Il. 5.288. Without verb, πρὶν ὥρη, ‘before it is time,’ Od. 15.394.
From A Homeric Dictionary (Georg Autenrieth, New York, Harper and Brothers, 1891)
